page.title: 14HUMSHAUGH ECOLOGY
page.content: THIS IS A{CONSERVATION}AREA AND SOME OF THE LAND IS INCLUDED IN THE NATIONAL PARK. TREES ARE IMPORTANT AND WELL SCATTERED OVER THE AREA ALTHOUGH ELM TREE DISEASE HAS TAKEN ITS TOLL. SEVERAL PLANTATIONS IN THE AREA ARE MAINLY CONIFERS BUT FRINGED BY A VARIETY OF DECIDUOUS TREES ABOVE BLACK CARTS SOME 300 HARDWOOD TREES HAVE BEEN PLANTED TO ENCOURAGE WILD LIFE. THE MAIN ROADS HAVE WIDE GRASS VERGES WHICH CONTAIN A GOOD VARIETY OF FLOWERS AND ALTHOUGH THE QUARRY AT HEATHERIDGE IS DRY, IT IS RAPIDLY BECOMING COLONISED BY SMALL TREES AND SHRUBS. SOME{FOOTPATHS}TEND TO BE OVERGROWN WITH A LARGE VARIETY OF GRASSES AND PLENTY OF WILD FLOWERS. NOT SO MANY{BIRDS}ABOUT; PIGEONS IN THE PLANTATION, ROOKS ON THE FIELDS AND A FLUTTERING OF SMALL BIRDS IN THE HEDGES.
